results.title: Fire can be a friend
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Fire is a natural part of the Australian environment. Fire has been such a dominant factor that many native plants are adapted to periodic burning. Due to the supression of natural fires many square kilometres are being choked by a dense sea of invading shrubs.

results.title: Yellow dog dingo
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Graziers have claimed for years that the dingo is responsible for heavy stock losses, specially among sheep. The Australian Meat Research Committee responded by earmarking funds for a scientific study of the dog. A team from the CSIRO’s Division of Wildlife Research in Canberra was mobilised in 1966 to carry out the study. Across Central Australia and the East Coast, the dogs were observed, tracked and examined in their own domain for thousands of hours. The difficulty it seems is that there is no one answer for dingo management in the scientific sense for any place in Australia and any one answer therefore for all of Australia. Management will have to be much more flexible, changing from place to place and from time to time.

results.title: An Open book for the disabled
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Displays an automated microfiche reader developed at CSIRO’s Division of Manufacturing Technology in Adelaide, which promises to make the printed word more readily accessible to the physically handicapped.

results.title: New mineral detector
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Sirotem embodies Australian solutions to the shortcomings of overseas electronic devices trying to detect minerals hidden beneath our difficult types of soil. Sirotem foreshadows the development of other exploration tools from this revolutionary Australian technology.

results.title: In a nutshell
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Australian gum trees are of considerable economic importance in various parts of the world. This demand is met by providing gum seeds to the countries that want our nuts.

results.title: Famous women of the past
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: The Queen of Sheba
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Famous women of the past”.
Strange and dramatic pages from the lives of the world’s most famous women. The Queen of Sheba having heard of King Solomon’s wisdom, travels across the desert to Jerusalem to meet him. The journey is one of the greatest overland journeys in history. On her arrival, the King greets her with majestic splendour, cordiality and hospitality. After a six-month stay, the Queen decides to return home. Following a sumptuous banquet in her honour, King Solomon tricks the Queen and satisfies his lust for this woman of great beauty and deep intelligence. The Queen of Sheba returns home and gives birth to a son. King Soloman never sees the Queen again but does finally meet his 16 yeaer old son, who later becomes the King of Abyssinia.

results.title: Delilah
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Famous women of the past”
Aided by the art of famous painters, this documentary tells the tail of Delilah, the biblical character, outcast and lover of Samson. Victim of savage gossip, she is burnt to death by Samson’s jealous Philistines.

results.title: Cleopatra and Antony
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Famous women of the past”.
Cleopatra, Queen of Egypt, friend and lover of Caesar, Roman Emperor. He is murdered, but she has a son, Caesarion. She is determined to have Caesar’s nephew, Octavian, (Emperor of Rome), removed and Caesarean in his place. To help the process she tries to befriend Mark Antony, the great Roman warrior. Antony succumbs to Cleopatra, and their relationship becomes unbreakable. Antony declares war on Rome to bring Caesarion to the throne - but after ten years of war, does not succeed, and their tragic deaths soon follow.
